instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01041: What is 820-01041? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  Troubleshooting damage that extends beyond the CD3215s
threads.message:
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>

5v does not switch to 20v
<CHIP>U3200</CHIP> (<CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>) gets hot (thermal imaging) regardless of port used.
Upon close inspection I discover that there is residue around ball 91 on <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> indicating that a surge has probably taken place.

Diode checking L3200 indicates both the <SIGNAL>USB2_UPC_XB</SIGNAL> N & P are shorted.
removing L3200 only (N) is shorted to <CHIP>U1200</CHIP>.  It is also shorted on the other side from the other set of <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>'s but the short stays on the <CHIP>U1200</CHIP> side when isolated.  I am sure <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> is smoked!  


My next step would be to change <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> and <CHIP>U1200</CHIP>?

I don't have much experience with this LB and would like advice from those who have been there.

Thanks
Randall

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  Troubleshooting damage that extends beyond the CD3215s
threads.message:
You  must change the chips identified as shorted.
Once removed (one by one), check if short went off.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  Troubleshooting damage that extends beyond the CD3215s
threads.message:
I know.   
have you seen this before?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  Troubleshooting damage that extends beyond the CD3215s
threads.message:
When a <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> got burn with hole in, I saw damaged PCH/CPU too.
In such case, because of direct connection, overvoltage can go from 20V input untill PCH/CPU.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  Troubleshooting damage that extends beyond the CD3215s
threads.message: What should I check before I even attempt changing it

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  Troubleshooting damage that extends beyond the CD3215s
threads.message:
You can't check all the lines corresponding to PCH, or CPU.
Can measure diode mode in the lines from PCH to <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips; but this basic check don't discard other problems.

If you have time to spend with it, remove PCH and check if low values detected disappear.
Then resolder PCH and pray nothing more important got damaged.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  Troubleshooting damage that extends beyond the CD3215s
threads.message:
Well  split balling a donor for <CHIP>U1200</CHIP> went perfectly.  "I was lucky"
replaced the damaged <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>.   My shorts are all gone.

Board still does not switch to 20V and the only thing glowing in thermal is the (T2)!
So unless I can change a T2 I am toast!
